title: Proposal title
text:
Dataset
The “Great American Coffee Taste Test” data set is compiled of survey results that were filled out by participants of a taste test, hosted in part by a coffee company Cometeer. Cometeer had sent 4 different types of coffee without labels to over 4,000 participants. The survey includes questions about coffee drinking habits, coffee preferences, individual taste test results for each of the 4 provides coffees, and individual demographics.
I chose this data set because I was curious about the demographics and preferences of coffee drinkers, both of customers of Cometeer and as a representation of the general North American population.

# loading data

coffee_survey <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-05-14/coffee_survey.csv')

head(coffee_survey)

title: Proposal title
text:
Questions
The two questions* I want to answer:

How do coffee drinking habits correlate with working and lifestyle situations?
What combinations of coffee characteristics are the most popular?

*Because this is a solo project, I only need to answer 1 question. For now, I will be attempting to answer both of these, focusing on Question 1.

title: Proposal title
text:
Analysis plan
A plan for answering each of the questions including the variables involved, variables to be created (if any), external data to be merged in (if any).

Variables: cups, employment_status, number_children, wfh

I plan to create a grouped bar plot, of the count of amount of cups drunken per day (“cups”), which will be grouped by position for work status (“employment_status”) and then color will indicate work from home status (“wfh”). I also want to find a way to incorporate number of children (“number_children”), as raising children is a form of labor and should be considered in lifestyle situations.

Variables: strength, roast_level, caffeine

To make it easier to visualize, I will mutate the “strength”, “roast_level”, and “caffeine” variables from categorical to numeric variables, assigning an appropriate number scale (for example, 1-5 for “Weak” to “Very strong” strength). I then intend to create a contour plot of the three variables, visualizing what combination of the three is the most popular coffee consumed. This could be helpful to know for Cometeer, which coffee could be the most profitable to produce.

title: About
text: This project was developed by Vera Soloview Jackson For INFO 526 - Data Analysis and Visualization at the University of Arizona, taught by Dr. Greg Chism. Vera is in her first year of the Master’s of Science in Data Science program at the University of Arizona.

title: Project title
text:
Math Expressions
You can write LaTeX math expressions inside a pair of dollar signs, e.g. $\alpha+\beta$ renders \(\alpha + \beta\). You can use the display style with double dollar signs:
$$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$
\[
\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i
\]
Limitations:

The source code of a LaTeX math expression must be in one line, unless it is inside a pair of double dollar signs, in which case the starting $$ must appear in the very beginning of a line, followed immediately by a non-space character, and the ending $$ must be at the end of a line, led by a non-space character;
There should not be spaces after the opening $ or before the closing $.

title: Project title
text:
Feeling adventurous?

You are welcomed to use the default styling of the slides. In fact, that’s what I expect majority of you will do. You will differentiate yourself with the content of your presentation.
But some of you might want to play around with slide styling. Some solutions for this can be found at https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs.
